blocks.text:
JULY 14 - 21, 1962: A WEEK IN THE POCONOS
Gordon, Kitty and Louise spend a week at Lake Wallenpaupack with the John D. Rohrbach family.
Sunset over the lake, as seen from the porch of the cottage.
(Nancy is taking graduate courses at Harvard; Cindy is employed for the summer at the Conestoga National Bank; Kathy is on a trip to California.)

With the Hamakers
August - Kitty spends almost a week with the David Ross family at Stone Harbor, N. J.
August 15, 1962 - Louise with Kitty and Gordon on her 16th birthday.

A week previously Cindy and Louise, with the help of Nancy and Kathy in absentia, stage a surprise anniversary party attended by more than twenty five couples. Kitty and Gordon survey the presents.

blocks.text: Bear Mountain Bridge across Hudson River.

In Boston with Nancy and her roommate, Helen (left). Cindy remains overnight, planning to drive Renault home Sunday. Gordon, Kitty and Louise head up North Shore for Maine, to return to Boston on Wednesday to take Nancy along home.

As we learn later, Cindy gets a late start on Sunday for return trip to Lancaster, Renault breaks down in New Jersey, and she manages to get to Lancaster by Monday night, leaving Renault behind for repairs and for us to pick up as we pass through New Jersey.
Many bays and inlets provide harbor for all types of private craft.
Salem's homes reflect early prosperity when sailing vessels brought wealth from West Indies and China.
The city of Salem and Nathaniel Hawthorne are closely associated. Here author was born in 1804.

blocks.text: Gloucester remains a picturesque fishing port. It is said more than 8,000 of her fishermen have lost their lives in the treacherous Grand Banks.

Rockport, also on Cape Ann,
is noted for its artist colony. This lobster hut is recognized as motif #1 along the Atlantic coast.
Rockport harbor crowded with yachts and fishing boats.
After dark inspection of antique and gift shops. Louise adds to her charm bracelet.

blocks.text: Night in motel near Newbury, Mass.
Nubble Light on small island off Cape Neddick.
Kitty selects a jug of doubtful antiquity.
A "flea circus" along Route l, where all kinds of antiques, furniture and plain junk can be gotten.

The lobster is Maine's chief contribution
to gastronomy. Gordon and Kitty savor a
succulent crustacean.
The Wedding Cake House at Kennebunk with most unusual trim. Story is a local swain wanted to give his bride something different.

blocks.text:
Lighthouses on Cape Elizabeth,
south of Portland. The upper light shows the lesser known
light located on a dead end road where tourists rarely
penetrate. The lower picture is Portland Head Light, probably the best known light
on the Atlantic coast, seen often on advertising and travel literature.
Time out for a lobster roll! Time out for a lobster roll!, a Maine drive-in delicacy consisting of lobster meat on what appears to be two pieces of bread joined at one end.
In Brunswick the house where Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote "Uncle Tom's Cabin" ...now an inn.

blocks.text: Windjammer cruises out of Camden, town noted for beautiful old mansions, surrounding hills and present day music festivals. At this point, we are still trying to locate Cindy by phone to ascertain why she has not gotten home from Boston.

Castine, located on east shore of Penobscot Bay, is home of Maine Marine Academy (training vessel shown). A sleepy little village today, site was witness to conflict during French & Indian and Revolutionary Wars.
OPEN on SUNDAYS
A late lunch at the outskirts of Ellsworth as we heard for Bar Harbor and Mount Desert Island, which contains most of Acadia Nat. Park., .
At Blue Hill, visit Rowantrees Killin where we buy samples of their handmade pottery. A complete set in Eisenhower's Gettysburg home.

(right) Echo Lake and Franconia Notch. An aerial tramway carries passengers to the top of Cannon Mountain.
The Old Man of the Mountains, a natural granite profile at Franconia Notch, was inspiration for Hawthorne's Great Stone Face. The sign gives statistics.
Tourists' lure! Bears pull up cans filled with food that tourists buy for them.

blocks.text: Night at motel near Alton.
(Left) Along the western shore of Lake Winnipesaukee, New Hampshire's largest lake...72 square miles of water surface. Accommodations for tourists and vacationers are everywhere.

Intermittent rain to Lexington,
where on April 19, 1775 was fired "the shot heard around the world", curtain-raiser to Revolutionary War. At Concord (pictures) replica of North Bridge where Minute men forced British to begin retreat to Boston. Minuteman statue by D. C. French.
On to Boston on too pick up Nancy in early afternoon.
Helping Nancy to load the car as she says good bye to Harvard.

In New Jersey, near Paterson, we retrieve the Renault where Cindy had been forced to abandon it due to breakdown. Nancy and Louise follow Gordon and Kitty to Lancaster, arriving several hours after midnight.
Bye to Harvard.
Manchester and New Hampshire.
End - trip to Boston, Maine and New Hampshire.

blocks.text: February 16-17: Trip to Penn State to visit Cindy. Gordon, Kitty, Kathy and Louise. 358 miles total trip. Night at new Holiday Inn.

First trip in new 1963 Buick Electra 225,
purchased the night before in Philadelphia.
Car is silver gray, four-door hardtop, with
electric windows and seat, power steering
and brakes.
Cindy so excited to see a new car she rushes out without a coat in 20 degrees weather.
Lunch at a drive-in north of Harrisburg.

Cindy, as usual,
wants steak, so
we drive to the
Eutaw House for
dinner.
Long stone-arch railroad bridge across the Susquehanna River.

The new president of Franklin and Marshall College,
Keith Spalding (center), is welcomed by the local
alumni at a banquet at Hotel Brunswick. James Trost
(left) is president of the local alumni association,
while Gordon is president of the Alumni Council, the
overall governing body (newspaper photograph).
Kathy again this year rates a newspaper picture in announcing the annual show of the Dolphin Club of Millersville State College (newspaper photograph).

blocks.text: Meeting of the Alumni Council of Franklin and Marshall College at Hamilton Club. Gordon retires as president. Members of Council: Wimer, Hartwick, Kephart, West, Jenkins, Walker (new president), Peifer (secretary), Landreth (retiring pres.), Showers, Klinges, Whitehead, Ryder, Ripple. May 31, 1963.

The following day Gordon presides at Class Day exercises; and on June 2 presents the College Torch to the graduating seniors at Commencement in the presence of Ex-President Eisenhower and Governor Scranton of Pennsylvania.
See last page this book for 176th Annual Commencement program.

blocks.text:
A TRIP TO FLORIDA AND NASSAU
June 20 - July 2, 1963: Gordon and Kitty accompanied by Nancy who leaves them in Miami for five weeks of island-hopping in the Caribbean.
Johnstown Windber
Baltimore

When we left Lancaster
we had no intention of going to Nassau (at least Gordon didn't); decision reached on second day of trip.

pages.full_text:
A TRIP TO FLORIDA AND NASSAU
June 20 - July 2, 1963: Gordon and Kitty accompanied by Nancy who leaves them in Miami for five weeks of island-hopping in the Caribbean.

Johnstown Windber

Baltimore

When we left Lancaster
we had no intention of going to Nassau (at least Gordon didn't); decision reached on second day of trip.

blocks.text: FIRST DAY: Thursday, June 20, 1963. Lancaster, Pa. to New Bern, N. C., by way of Delmarva Peninsula, across Chesapeake Bay. 445 miles. 8:00 A. M. to 8:45 P. M.
Good start - 8:00 A. M.
After 183 miles, the Maryland-Virginia line.
Who ever heard of a town named Birdsnest?
Pictures by Leica M-3; most with f1.5 lens; a few using long focus lens.

Total 3,515 miles by car,
plus boat trip to Nassau.

Ancestor of Martha Washington buried here,
near tip of Cape Charles, Va.

blocks.text: Brief wait to board the "Pocahontas" which will take us across the mouth of Chesapeake Bay, a trip. Fare is $5.55. Probably our last trip here by ferry, since a new bridge-tunnel-causeway complex will soon be completed.
Barely visible in the distance is part of the $200 million bridge-tunnel-causeway, 17.6 miles, world's longest, scheduled to be opened to traffic early in 1964.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY: Friday, June 21, 1963. New Bern, N. C. almost to Georgia–Florida line, via Wilmington, N. C., Charleston, S. C. and Savannah, Ga. 500 miles; total 945 miles. 8:20 A. M. to 9:15 P. M.

At Wilmington, the battleship "North Carolina", 729',
350,000 tons, tied up in the Cape Fear River. Now on
public exhibition, the giant ship was saved from
being scrapped by subscription among N. C. citizens.
The South Carolina Carolineline. Dense woodland except for roadside stands which offer a wide selection of fireworks, banned in most states.
Myrtle Beach, South Carolina's seashore resort town.

Route #17 continues through deep forests and swampland,
with few towns and poor farms.
The Cooper River Bridge (toll free), approach to Charleston, S. C.

blocks.text:
Charleston, known as
"America's most historic city", was settled in 1670 by the English. Located at junction of Cooper and Ashley rivers.
Famous in the affairs of the colonies.
Replete with old and stately buildings.
In the harbor is Fort Sumter on a tiny island, against which first shots were fired in the War between the States.
Charleston is unbelievably hot and humid; we remain only a short time.
Across the swamp flats as we near Savannah; later we by-pass Brunswick on a new road as darkness falls; continue on to near Florida line.

THIRD DAY: Saturday, June 22, 1963. Florida–Georgia line to Pompano Beach, Fla.
Most of travel along Atlantic Ocean. 391 miles; total 1,336 miles.
. Enter Florida in the early morning; pause at one of the state's official welcoming stations.

blocks.text: Avoid Jacksonville traffic by taking road east to Fernandina Beach and crossing St. Johns River (above) to Mayport. Follow coast to Saint Augustine.
A gas war at Jacksonville Beach; we fill the tank; also receive a box of soap powder and green trading stamps.
All alone with the Ocean as we follow the coastal road to Saint Augustine.

Saint Augustine, one of two oldest cities in the U. S. Quaint old Spanish buildings and narrow streets. Founded 1565. Shown are City Gate, part of original wall of 1620; and old wooden schoolhouse. Hot and humid - and another short stay. Continue down the coast.

blocks.text: Flagler Beach, named for Henry M. Flagler who did so much to develop the state.
Lighthouse just south of Saint Augustine.
Contemplation of land, sea and sky.

Almost dark when we reach Palm Beach, one of the most fashionable resorts in the U. S. Most of the large, elaborate homes closed for the season.
Palm Beach an island 18 miles long, 3/4 mile wide.

blocks.text: FOURTH DAY: Sunday, June 23, 1963. Pompano Beach, to Miami Beach, to Coral Gables for motel. Two trips to Miami International Airport. Including travel on Monday; total 1,476 miles.
This de luxe motel at Pompano Beach is $7.21 for three in this "off season".
The streets of glittering Miami Beach are almost deserted in early Sunday morning.
Cross the causeway to Miami.
Jet plane from California arrives at 4:50 P. M. Nancy Galloway (center), whom Nancy met at Harvard last summer, and Julie Beck will accompany Nancy on her island-hopping tour.
Secure motel in Coral Gables for five ($15) in anticipation arrival of Nancy's friends from California. Kitty goes for a swim.
Gordon and Kitty arrange trip to Nassau on S/S YARMOUTH. Fare for both is $130, plus $8 tax – a bargain!

A calypso band furnishes music each night.
Entering Nassau harbor at 7:30 A. M. Luxurious British Colonial Hotel at entrance.

blocks.text: Trouble on Bay Street where the white merchant aristocracy collects most of the tourist dollars. On our last afternoon in Nassau a meeting is called to protest unemployment and high food prices. There is no violence, the native police keep the situation well in hand, but the meeting may foretell a change in the scheme of things.

Native souvenirs. Kitty is determined to have a bongo drum, so just prior to the boat's departure she ventures alone into the native section in search for a bargain. Result: this drum from Haiti - is the largest we have seen, purchased after much haggling for $10. Tourists guess it cost $30. It becomes a little cumbersome to get through customs.
The "Yarmouth" leaves Nassau at 6:00 P. M. for the overnight return trip to Miami.

blocks.text: NINTH DAY: Friday, June 28, 1963. Gordon and Kitty return to Miami aboard "Yarmouth" at 7:00 A. M., leave ship 9:00 A. M; through Everglades National Park; across Fla. Keys to Key West. 274 miles; total (by car) 1,750 miles. Arrive Key West 5:30 P.M.

From Miami drive directly to Homestead and Florida City; then 12 miles to entrance Everglades National Park, a subtropical wilderness of more than 2,100 square miles of land and water, larger than the state of Delaware. Here are found miles of sawgrass, clusters of trees called hammocks forming islands of dense vegetation in the open glades, vast swamps and placid waterways. There is a great diversity of marine, plant, bird, animal and reptile life.
The Everglades - "River of Grass". Kitty sheds her shoes for greater comfort.
A white bird (a heron or an egret) flies over the waving grass, while a lone crow perches at the very top of one of the few high trees.

pages.full_text:
NINTH DAY: Friday, June 28, 1963. Gordon and Kitty return to Miami aboard "Yarmouth" at 7:00 A. M., leave ship 9:00 A. M; through Everglades National Park; across Fla. Keys to Key West. 274 miles; total (by car) 1,750 miles. Arrive Key West 5:30 P.M.

From Miami drive directly to Homestead and Florida City; then 12 miles to entrance Everglades National Park, a subtropical wilderness of more than 2,100 square miles of land and water, larger than the state of Delaware. Here are found miles of sawgrass, clusters of trees called hammocks forming islands of dense vegetation in the open glades, vast swamps and placid waterways. There is a great diversity of marine, plant, bird, animal and reptile life.

The Everglades - "River of Grass". Kitty sheds her shoes for greater comfort.

blocks.text: Boardwalks across the swamps lead to a number of hammocks.
Ruins of a mangrove grove forest from the hurricane of last year. Kitty tries to ease the agony of several dozen bites from marraudaing insects.
Far in the distance a tropical storm covers the sky. It strikes with brief but intense fury.
. rare birds .

Thirty nine miles from the gateway to the park is Flamingo where the Government has built a museum, a restaurant, a motel, a marina and campgrounds. Most are run by concessions. Supplies must be brought from Florida City.

blocks.text: Kitty waves from the car as we approach Key West, southernmost point in the United States and end of Route #1, 157 miles from Miami by direct route. Arrive 5:40 P.M., locate this motel with tropical garden. It's hot - 92 degrees.
See previous trip in 1955.

TENTH DAY: Saturday, June 29, 1963. Key West, return across Keys, along Everglades north west coast of Florida to Tarpon Springs. 458 miles; total 2,208 miles.
7:15 A. M. (several hours in Key West) to 9:00 P. M.
Key West has an Old World look with narrow streets and weathered houses. Much Spanish still spoken. Only ninety miles from Cuba, but no intercourse since the advent of Castro.

blocks.text: The lighthouse within the corporate limits of the town.
Spend two hours of the morning in Key West ...return Overseas Highway to Homestead... due north through lime and lemon orchards to connect with Tamiami Trail about 18 mi. west of Miami.

The Tamiami Trail (a contraction of Tampa and Miami), U. S. 41, cuts straight across the Everglades, was 12 years in the making.
There are several gas stations, a few Seminole Indian huts and very little else except endless saw grass and the canal.
People, many of them colored, fish in the canal. At a few locations airboats are available for trips through the swamps.

blocks.text: Everglades, four miles from the Trail at the western edge of the vast Park. Noted for hunting and fishing. Unusual sign invites tourists to ring bell and a boat will come for them.
Across the Calooschatchee River at Ft. Myers; a new bridge is under construction.
At Naples, farthest south of West Coast cities, 1,000 ft. fishing pier into Gulf.

Shell factory north of Fort Myers said to be world's largest. We are induced to sign up for a chance on a lot in a new development...receive literature for months after we get home.
New York, S.C.
North across Sunshine Skyway over Tampa Bay as darkness falls.

blocks.text: ELEVENTH DAY: Sunday, June 30, 1963. Tarpon Springs, north through central Florida, into Georgia as far as Milledgeville. 434 miles; total 2,642 miles. 10 A. M. to 8:00 P. M.

Breakfast in Tarpon Springs...colorful Greek sponge fleet, largest in U. S.... buy souvenirs for children at home... Kitty inspects a very dead porcupine fish.
Kitty innspercccds a very deadly pooroorcupsinne fish.

Head inland... farm country... cigar tobacco (above) and ripe watermelons... due north from Lake City to Georgia line through dense woodlands.. .200 miles so far in 3½ hrs., average 57 mi. per hr... light rain hrs., , average 577 mi.

blocks.text: TWELFTH DAY: Monday, July 1, 1963. Milledgeville, Ga., north to Asheville, N. C., travel Blue Ridge Parkway for ninety miles, night at Boone, N. C. 390 miles; total 3,032 miles.

Milledgeville, Ga., north to Asheville, N. C.,
5 miles, night at Boone, N. C. 390 miles; total M.
Purchase tree-ripened peaches along highway in north-central Georgia. Season is far ahead of ours at home.
We consider prices on the high side, probably due to Pennsylvania license on car.

. Enter North Carolina; east in heavy traffic to Asheville; climb to Blue Ridge Parkway; encounter rain and mist which spoil mountain views; leave Parkinson at Grandfather Mt.; locate motel near Boone. Note many new enterprises to separate the tourist from his dollar.
THIRTEENTH DAY: Tuesday, July 2, 1963. Boone, N. C. to Roanoke, Va., northeast thru Shenandoah Valley, into West Virginia, Maryland and home. 483 miles; total 3,515 miles. 6:30 A. M. to 7:15 P. M.

Follow winding mountain roads without again rising to Parkway. Learn from gas station attendant Landreths are settled in this northwestern corner of North Carolina and near Galax, Va. Roanoke at 11:30 A. M. after 200 miles. Call Perry Kendig to learn he has just been elected president of Roanoke College. Buy peanuts in many forms at peanut house. Heavy rains encountered as we head north in Shenandoah Valley. Home at 7:15 P. M.

End - trip to Florida and Nassau.
3,515 miles by car, plus boat trip to Nassau.
